statement:
For a continuous-time stochastic process adapted to a given
$(\mathcal{F}_t)_{t\in\mathbb{R}_+}$ on a measurable space
$(\Omega,\mathcal{F})$, there are various conditions which can be placed
either on its sample paths or on its measurability when considered as a
function from $\mathbb{R}_+\times\Omega$ to $\mathbb{R}$. The following
theorem lists the dependencies between these properties.

Let $(X_t)_{t\in\mathbb{R}_+}$ be a real valued stochastic process.
Then, $X$ is optional if it is adapted and right-continuous, it is
predictable if it is adapted and left-continuous. Furthermore, each of
the following properties implies the next.

1.  $X$ is predictable.

2.  $X$ is optional.

3.  $X$ is progressive.

4.  $X$ is adapted and jointly measurable.
